Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Global Integrated Drought Monitoring and Prediction System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Global Integrated Drought Monitoring and Prediction System (GIDMaPS) is one of the first global multi-index drought monitoring and seasonal prediction systems. GIDMaPS provides near real-time drought information including persistence-based drought prediction using (a) soil moisture accumulations-based standardized soil moisture index (SSI); and (b) the newly developed Multivariate Standardized Drought Index (MSDI). The seasonal forecast component of GIDMaPS provides the probability of drought occurrence for different drought severity levels. The monitoring component of GIDMaPS presents drought information based on five categories of drought types: D0 (abnormally dry), D1 (moderate drought), D2 (severe drought), D3 (extreme drought), and D4 (exceptional drought). The seasonal drought prediction component is based on two input data sets available from NASA (MERRA and NLDAS) and three drought indicators (SPI, SSI, and MSDI). The outputs of the seasonal prediction component are probability of drought occurrence. To date, most studies and models have explored droughts monitoring using univariate indicators (e.g., SPI). As an alternative to currently available univariate drought indices, GIDMaPS includes a novel multivariate multi-index approach (MSDI) which provides a composite assessment of both agricultural and meteorological droughts.

The proposed innovation could be useful to a broad list of customers including (a) commodity investors; (b) insurance and re-insurance companies; (c) energy companies; (d) private farmers; (e) government agencies, such as the United States Department of Agriculture; and (f) state agencies, such as the Department of Water Resources. Commodity investors, for example, need seasonal predictions (1-6 months) at the global scale since droughts in several countries can affect global food prices. For this reason, GIDMaPS outputs can be used to make investment decisions. Furthermore, the proposed methodology has the potential to improve the current capabilities of the U.S. Drought Monitor which only provides monitoring information without any drought prediction. Finally, in the past decade, several drought events led to famine, resulting in loss of lives and dire societal impacts. GIDMaPS can provide drought early warning and potentially be used for managing drought relieve operations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Global Integrated Drought Monitoring and Prediction System (GIDMaPS) is the first global multi-index drought monitoring and seasonal prediction system. GIDMaPS provides near real-time drought information including persistence-based drought prediction using precipitation, soil moisture, and a newly developed Multivariate Standardized Drought Index (MSDI). The latter provides a composite assessment of both agricultural and meteorological droughts. The seasonal forecast component of GIDMaPS provides probability of drought occurrence for different drought severity levels. GIDMaPS can be useful to a broad list of users including farmers, commodity investors, energy companies and government agencies.

The objective of this project was translating our basic research (GIDMaPS) to the marketplace. The outcomes of the project include:

(a) Assessing the market through online and onsite presentations and through the UC Irvine Office of Technology Alliances portal. After interviewing numerous experts in the field, the team concluded that GIDMaPS can be tailored for private farmers. The team attended several farmer conventions and interviewed over one hundred farmers. Through these interviews, the team received feedback on how GIDMaPS should be modified and presented to be useful to farmers. The team also attended science conferences to present GIDMaPS and receive feedback on how it can be improved and commercialized.

 

(b) The project has led to the following US Patent application:

Drought Monitoring and Prediction Tools, A AghaKouchak, Z Hao, N Nakhjiri, US Patent App. 14/278,525, Submitted May 2014.

 

(c) Based on the feedback received from the farmers and other scientists, the team has developed a mobile app that will be commercialized in the next few months (Figure 1). The app is already developed and is now being tested. We expect to release a trial version by September 2015, and a commercial version in 2016. The app allows users to click on any location on the map of the United States and extract information on the recent past and seasonal prediction (see sample map in Figure 1 (middle panel)). The GIDMaPS app also provides other weather information relevant to farmers such as precipitation and temperature (Figure 1 (left panel)). Finally, the app includes search options and allows users to add or remove the information layers they are interested in (Figure 1 (right panel)).
